slides.slide_text: Ionic bonds are a type of chemical bond formed between atoms when there is a complete transfer of valence electrons from one atom to another. This transfer results in the formation of ions - one atom loses electrons and becomes positively charged, known as a cation, while the other atom gains electrons and becomes negatively charged, known as an anion. These ions are attracted to each other due to their opposite charges, resulting in the formation of an ionic bond.

Ionic bonds are commonly formed between atoms of different elements, typically a metal and a non-metal. This is because metals tend to have low electronegativity, meaning they have a tendency to lose electrons, while non-metals have high electronegativity and tend to gain electrons.

The strength of an ionic bond depends on several factors, including the charge of the ions and the distance between them. Generally, the stronger the charge on the ions and the closer they are to each other, the stronger the ionic bond will be.

Ionic compounds form crystal lattices, in which positive and negative ions are arranged in a repeating pattern. Since the ions in an ionic compound are held together by strong electrostatic attractions, these compounds tend to have high melting and boiling points.

In summary, ionic bonds occur when there is a complete transfer of valence electrons between atoms. This results in the formation of oppositely charged ions, leading to strong attractions between them. Ionic compounds form crystal lattices and typically have high melting and boiling points. Understanding how ionic bonds work is essential in comprehending the properties and behavior of a wide range of chemical compounds.
